    Constructors in cs3318.group17.raytracer with parameters of type Vector
    Modifier
    Constructor
    Description
     
    Ray(Point origin, Vector direction)
    Constructs a Ray which moves from a Point of origin along a given direction Vector.
     
    Ray(Point origin, Vector direction, boolean adjustForError)
    Constructs a Ray which moves from a Point of origin along a given direction Vector.
     
    RayHit(Ray ray, Shape shape, Vector normal, double t, boolean entering)
    RayHit is a class which computes and then stores all the information produced when a Ray is incident upon a Shape including: the references to which Ray and Shape are involved in the intersection, the Point of incidence, the normal to the surface of Shape at the Point of incidence, the length along the Ray at which the Point of incidence occurs and whether the Ray is entering or exiting the Shape if that shape is transparent.
     
    RayHit(Ray ray, Shape shape, Vector normal, Point intersection, boolean entering)
    Same as RayHit(Ray, Shape, Vector, double, boolean) but Point of intersection is given and length t along ray is computed instead.

    Computes the halfway vector between the incident and reflected Ray used in the Blinn-Phong reflection model.
    Vector
    Vector.minus(Vector v)
    Returns a Vector found by subtracting the corresponding elements of v from the current Vector.
    Vector
    Vector.negate()
    Flips the direction of the current Vector.
    Vector
    Vector.normalize()
    The magnitude of a Vector is equivalent to the length of a line drawn from the base of that Vector to its tip.
    Vector
    Vector.plus(Vector v)
    Returns a Vector found by adding the corresponding elements of the current Vector and the Vector v.
    Vector
    Matrix.times(Vector v)
    Implements Matrix multiplication with a Vector v.
    Vector
    Vector.times(double scalar)
    A Vector v times a scalar c results in a new Vector pointing in the same direction as the original Vector but has magnitude equal to c multiplied by the magnitude of v.
